American Apparel Board Moves to Fire Founder, CEO Dov Charney

summary-body.p: American Apparel's board moved Wednesday to fire founder and Chief Executive Dov Charney, citing an "ongoing investigation into alleged misconduct."

headline.main-hed: American Apparel Board Moves to Fire Founder, CEO Dov Charney
headline.deck: American Apparel Board Cites 'Ongoing Investigation Into Alleged Misconduct'

media.media-caption: Dov Charney, founder and chief executive officer of American Apparel Inc., shown in 2010.

article-body.p: American Apparel Inc.'s board moved Wednesday to fire founder and Chief Executive Dov Charney, citing an "ongoing investigation into alleged misconduct."

The move kicks off a fight at the top of the company, which is already struggling with poor results and debt. The board wouldn't specify the allegations but said it intends to fire Mr. Charney for cause once a 30-day period to resolve the conflict called for in the CEO's contract expires. The company said the move could leave it in default under its credit agreement, prompting discussion with its lenders.

Mr. Charney founded American Apparel as a wholesale T-shirt business in 1998. He parted ways with much of the industry by electing to produce the garments in America while becoming an outspoken advocate of immigration reform and better wages.

The CEO used sexuality to sell his clothes and frankly discussed his own sex life, sometimes wandering around his factory in his underpants. Mr. Charney found himself at the center of sexual-harassment lawsuits brought by former employees.
The board named Chief Financial Officer John Luttrell as interim CEO and named public relations executive and board member Allan Mayer as co-chairman along with David Danziger.
It wasn't immediately possible to reach Mr. Charney.
As of May 31, American Apparel had about 10,000 employees and operated 249 retail stores in 20 countries.

The moves come after the company in May reported a net loss of $5.5 million for the three months ended March 31, narrower than the $46.5 million loss it reported a year earlier. Comparable-store sales fell 7%.

The Los Angeles-based maker of casual clothing had enlisted lawyers at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP to work on restructuring options, people familiar with the matter said earlier this year. The move came as some of the company's bondholders had started to organize, the people said.

The company has struggled over the years, coming close to breaching loan covenants—debt terms designed to protect its lenders—some of the people said. The company in late January said it refinanced the majority of its debt.

Mr. Charney and members of the board have been embroiled in several cases filed in courts in New York and Los Angeles asserting claims of "sexual harassment, assault and battery, impersonation through the internet, defamation, and other related claims," according to an American Apparel regulatory filing in April. The company was awaiting an arbitrator's ruling on an evidentiary hearing held to evaluate these claims in at least one case as of the time of the filing.
Mr. Charney is the company's largest individual shareholder, with about 27% of American Apparel stock, according to S&P Capital IQ.
article-body.tagline: Sara Germano contributed to this article.
article-body.p: Write to Suzanne Kapner at Suzanne.Kapner@wsj.com
